nodes.label: Karl Ove Knausgård
nodes.description: Norwegian author of the six-volume autobiographical novel series 'My Struggle'.

nodes.label: My Struggle: Book 1
nodes.description: The first installment of an epic exploration of the self, memory, and the mundane details of life.

nodes.label: Rachel Cusk
nodes.description: British novelist whose 'Outline' trilogy redefined the contemporary novel.

nodes.label: Outline
nodes.description: A novel told through a series of conversations, where the narrator's own story is revealed indirectly.

nodes.label: Sheila Heti
nodes.description: Canadian writer who blends fiction, philosophy, and autobiography.

nodes.label: How Should a Person Be?
nodes.description: A novel that uses real-life recordings and emails to explore questions of art and identity.

nodes.label: Ocean Vuong
nodes.description: Vietnamese American poet and novelist.

nodes.label: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous
nodes.description: An epistolary novel written as a letter from a son to his illiterate mother.

nodes.label: Ben Lerner
nodes.description: American poet, novelist, and critic, known for his autofictional works.

nodes.label: Leaving the Atocha Station
nodes.description: A novel about a young American poet in Madrid, grappling with authenticity and art.

nodes.label: Maggie Nelson
nodes.description: American writer whose work defies genre, blending memoir, criticism, and poetry.

nodes.label: The Argonauts
nodes.description: A work of 'autotheory' that explores gender, sexuality, and family.

nodes.label: Chris Kraus
nodes.description: American writer and filmmaker, a key figure in contemporary feminist writing.

nodes.label: I Love Dick
nodes.description: A cult classic that mixes fiction and memoir to explore obsession and female intellectualism.

nodes.label: Annie Ernaux
nodes.description: French writer and Nobel laureate, known for her autobiographical works.

nodes.label: The Years
nodes.description: A collective autobiography that captures the social and cultural history of France from the 1940s to the 2000s.

nodes.label: W. G. Sebald
nodes.description: German writer whose works blend fiction, travelogue, and history, often accompanied by photographs.

nodes.label: The Rings of Saturn
nodes.description: A novel recounting a walking tour of Suffolk, filled with historical and literary meditations.

nodes.label: Teju Cole
nodes.description: American novelist, photographer, and art historian.

nodes.label: Open City
nodes.description: A novel that follows a young Nigerian doctor wandering the streets of New York City.

nodes.label: Édouard Louis
nodes.description: French writer whose novels are based on his own experiences with poverty, class, and violence.

nodes.label: The End of Eddy
nodes.description: An autobiographical novel about growing up gay in a working-class village in northern France.

nodes.label: Deborah Levy
nodes.description: A British novelist, playwright, and poet.

nodes.label: The Cost of Living
nodes.description: The second part of her 'living autobiography' trilogy, exploring life after the end of a marriage.

nodes.label: Lydia Davis
nodes.description: An American short story writer, novelist, and translator, known for her very short, flash fiction.

nodes.label: The End of the Story
nodes.description: A novel that analyzes the end of a love affair with meticulous, obsessive detail.

nodes.label: Joan Didion
nodes.description: An American writer who launched her career in the 1960s after winning an essay contest sponsored by Vogue magazine.

nodes.label: The Year of Magical Thinking
nodes.description: A powerful account of the year following the death of her husband, John Gregory Dunne.

nodes.label: James Baldwin
nodes.description: An American novelist, playwright, essayist, poet, and activist.

nodes.label: Go Tell It on the Mountain
nodes.description: A semi-autobiographical novel that tells the story of John Grimes, a teenager in 1930s Harlem.

nodes.label: Marcel Proust
nodes.description: A French novelist, critic, and essayist who wrote the monumental novel In Search of Lost Time.

nodes.label: In Search of Lost Time
nodes.description: A seven-volume novel that explores themes of memory, time, and art, considered a precursor to autofiction.

nodes.label: Hervé Guibert
nodes.description: A French writer and photographer, a key figure in autofiction.

nodes.label: To the Friend Who Did Not Save My Life
nodes.description: A novel that chronicles the author's experience with AIDS.

nodes.label: Claudia Rankine
nodes.description: An American poet, essayist, and playwright.

nodes.label: Citizen: An American Lyric
nodes.description: A book-length poem/essay that recounts experiences of racism in America.

nodes.label: Hilton Als
nodes.description: An American writer and critic for The New Yorker magazine.

nodes.label: White Girls
nodes.description: A collection of essays that blend criticism, memoir, and fiction.

nodes.label: Maxine Hong Kingston
nodes.description: An American author and Professor Emerita at the University of California, Berkeley.

nodes.label: The Woman Warrior
nodes.description: A book that combines autobiography with Chinese folklore.

nodes.label: J. M. Coetzee
nodes.description: A South African and Australian novelist, essayist, linguist, translator and recipient of the 2003 Nobel Prize in Literature.

nodes.label: Summertime
nodes.description: A novel in which a fictional biographer attempts to piece together the life of the late writer, John Coetzee.

nodes.label: Ta-Nehisi Coates
nodes.description: An American author and journalist.

nodes.label: Between the World and Me
nodes.description: A book written as a letter to the author's teenage son about the feelings, symbolism, and realities associated with being Black in the United States.

nodes.label: Alison Bechdel
nodes.description: An American cartoonist.

nodes.label: Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic
nodes.description: A graphic memoir that chronicles the author's childhood and her relationship with her closeted gay father.

nodes.label: Art Spiegelman
nodes.description: An American cartoonist, editor, and comics advocate.

nodes.label: Maus
nodes.description: A graphic novel in which the author interviews his father about his experiences as a Polish Jew and Holocaust survivor.

nodes.label: Dave Eggers
nodes.description: An American writer, editor, and publisher.

nodes.label: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
nodes.description: A memoir about the author's experience raising his younger brother after their parents' deaths.

nodes.label: Henry Miller
nodes.description: An American writer. He was known for breaking with existing literary forms and developing a new type of semi-autobiographical novel.

nodes.label: Tropic of Cancer
nodes.description: A novel that describes the author's life as a struggling writer in Paris.

nodes.label: Anaïs Nin
nodes.description: A French-Cuban American diarist, essayist, novelist, and writer of short stories and erotica.

nodes.label: Henry and June
nodes.description: An account of the author's relationship with Henry Miller and his wife June.

nodes.label: Jack Kerouac
nodes.description: An American novelist and poet, a pioneer of the Beat Generation.

nodes.label: On the Road
nodes.description: A novel based on the travels of Kerouac and his friends across the United States.

nodes.label: Charles Bukowski
nodes.description: A German-American poet, novelist, and short story writer.

nodes.label: Post Office
nodes.description: An autobiographical novel about the author's years working as a mail carrier.

nodes.label: Hunter S. Thompson
nodes.description: An American journalist and author who founded the gonzo journalism movement.

nodes.label: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas
nodes.description: A novel that blurs the line between fact and fiction, describing a drug-fueled journey to Las Vegas.

nodes.label: Patricia Lockwood
nodes.description: An American poet, novelist, and essayist.

nodes.label: No One Is Talking About This
nodes.description: A novel that captures the experience of living online, told in a fragmented, autofictional style.

nodes.label: Autofiction
nodes.description: A form of fictionalized autobiography.

nodes.label: Memoir
nodes.description: A historical account or biography written from personal knowledge or special sources.

nodes.label: Self-reflexivity
nodes.description: A text that refers to its own artificiality or construction.

nodes.label: Identity
nodes.description: The fact of being who or what a person or thing is; a close similarity or affinity.

nodes.label: The Nature of Truth
nodes.description: A philosophical exploration of what constitutes truth and how it is represented in narrative.

nodes.label: Trauma
nodes.description: A deeply distressing or disturbing experience, often explored through personal narrative.

nodes.label: Confessional Literature
nodes.description: A genre of writing that reveals the author's private thoughts and experiences.

nodes.label: Fictionalized Self
nodes.description: The concept of the author creating a character who is a version of themselves, but not identical.

nodes.label: Essay-Novel
nodes.description: A hybrid form that combines the narrative elements of a novel with the discursive, reflective style of an essay.

nodes.label: Subjectivity
nodes.description: The quality of being based on or influenced by personal feelings, tastes, or opinions.

nodes.label: Memory
nodes.description: The faculty by which the mind stores and remembers information, a central theme in autobiographical writing.

nodes.label: Genre Blending
nodes.description: The mixing of different literary genres, such as fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and criticism.

nodes.label: The Body
nodes.description: An exploration of the physical body as a site of experience, trauma, and identity.

nodes.label: Class
nodes.description: The examination of social class and its impact on individual lives and experiences.

nodes.label: Gonzo Journalism
nodes.description: A style of journalism that is written without claims of objectivity, often including the reporter as part of the story.

edges.target: Go Tell It on the Mountain
To the Friend Who Did Not Save My Life
A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas
No One Is Talking About This

edges.source: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
To the Friend Who Did Not Save My Life
Go Tell It on the Mountain
Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas

commentary: Blur the line between reality and fiction with Autofiction, a genre of the self.
